ygData.subject: Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, I agree with Ken that regularities are preserved and elaborated during evolution (actually in the case of complexification). But there is another

Subject: Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=LsCz6gJbUZZ6aMoFKrvggytAQi9aj8BEYVr987xABS-Jx5QL38xxqq-hyg

Hi all, 

I agree with Ken that regularities are preserved and elaborated 
=
during evolution (actually in the case of complexification). But 
there is =
another question. Can we compare the genotype complexity for 
both models, =
what if the CPPN encodes a very complex function with 
many dimentions and =
the other method that produces the same results 
has less genes? I don't se=
e any info about genotype complexity on 
Picbreeder. And because most of th=
e interesting pictures have very 
long lineages, probably the mutation rate=
s are high too, it is 
possible that these examples have very complex genom=
es. More complex 
than it could be done with another method, cellurar growt=
h for 
example. Consider the square shape that Robert evolved. For a human'=
s 
perception it is very simple but there may be about hundreds of 
connect=
ions in the CPPN. 

By the way we should make difference between CPPN outpu=
t images, when 
we concern *bodies*. Because in the physics sense, a CPPN c=
an easily 
create hundreds of separate objects in one snapshot. There is a =

difference between the raw CPPN snapshot and a physical body in the 
sense=
 we want it to be. If I say "here is an apple" I usually mean 
one object. =
But a CPPN with structure capturing a repetition 
regularity can make infin=
ite number of apples. 

Another thing I'd like to discuss is how does it fi=
t into the fitness 
search. Suppose we need to evolve a "creature" with a s=
kin preserving 
the inner body intact. I really believe that all first moti=
fs of skin 
will fail. But on the other hand, Novelty Search would search t=
oo 
vast space before it ever finds the right motif. 

Peter

--- In neat@y=
ahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Jeff, that's a =
good thought experiment for testing my claim.  There
> are many considerati=
ons, and although I may not hit all of them, I
> think in general it can be=
 refuted:
> 
> Generally, I think HyperNEAT (i.e. NEAT with CPPNs) already
=
> approximately follow the scenario that you outline:  It discovers 
key
> =
motifs (whether they be skin or something else) early in evolution 
and
> t=
hen as the overall body plan is deformed, the original motifs are
> often p=
reserved (which again includes skin).  The main idea is that
> skin is like=
 a kind of surrounding motif for the overall shape, and 
if
> the pverall s=
hape is warped through some kind of mutation in the
> internal CPPN, then h=
owever the shape is surrounded will naturally
> warp in the same way.
> 
> =
In fact, you can see this happen consistently in Picbreeder.  It is
> possi=
ble to consider the simple black outline of many of the color
> figures as =
a "skin."  You can notice that it is special by noting 
that
> often the ou=
ter band is black but everything structure inside is
> color.  Then, if the=
 shape of the overall image warps, so does the
> outer membrane.
> 
> Howev=
er, you might say that such a "skin" is not complex enough to 
be
> convinc=
ing.  Perhaps skin should have multiple parts, i.e. its own
> special struc=
ture.  In fact, if you look closely, you can find many
> such examples.  Fo=
r example, there are often double-layer outer
> membranes that form, such a=
s in this image:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D317=

> 
> There is a clear outer structure that surrounds the complex 
curvatur=
e
> of the object.
> 
> Or, perhaps more interestingly, you can get several=
 layers of color
> bands, but only on the outer membrane, such as in this i=
mage that 
ends
> in a light blue that becomes green, then becomes yellow, =
before
> sinking into the inner-body color of orange:
> 
> http://picbreede=
r.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D4227
> 
> To show that the outer membrane=
 warps easily and naturally 
regardless
> of shape changes (even complex on=
es), I further evolved that image 
to
> get a new shape, and you can see th=
at the outer membrane has the 
same
> motif nevertheless, nicely warped to =
accommodate the new overall 
shape:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showg=
enome.php?sid=3D5635
> 
> It is also important to note that outer membranes=
 in nature are not
> uniform covers and often transition into something els=
e on the
> surface.  For example, consider lips and eyes.  Or perhaps even =
more
> importantly, consider fingernails, where the outer cover actually
> =
falls *under* something else (i.e. the nail), violating the covering
> rule=
.  I point these exceptions out because in Picbreeder you also
> often see =
almost consistent outer motifs that are broken in a couple
> places.  While=
 these locations often are arbitrary, the point is 
that
> such a capabilit=
y could be exploited if it actually mattered.
> 
> Moving from 2-D to 3-D s=
hould not matter in the case of skin, just 
as
> moving CPPNs from 2-D to 4=
-D continues to allow all the same
> regularities.  So when you see example=
s in 2-D, they are also 
possible
> in 3-D for the same reasons.
> 
> Most =
of these outer skin motifs can arise early when the shape is
> simple and a=
re then easily preserved.  However, they are not always
> preserved.  For e=
xample, the multicolor skin above evolved into a
> different multicolor ski=
n in one lineage:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D42=
28
> 
> This phenomenon is expected from the analogy with nature, just as
>=
 scales can evolve into fur, or fur into uncovered skin, all still
> servin=
g the role of outer membrane.
> 
> I think it's important to note that skin=
 or an outer membrane is not
> really any different from any other CPPN-gen=
erated motif, in that it
> can be preserved, warped, or changed in its inte=
rnal structure.  So 
I
> don't think there is really anything special going=
 on in the 
argument
> compared to the discovery of symmetry or other conve=
ntions.
> 
> ken 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wr=
ote:
> >
> > Hello all-
> > 
> > Ken has challenged us all many times to th=
ink about whether there 
is any
> > need for a process of development. The =
identity of cells in
> developmental
> > processes is determined by local c=
ontextual information whereas 
Ken
> > advocates skipping that by letting c=
ells determine their identity
> via giving
> > them their objective coordin=
ates. The question is whether we lose
> anything
> > important to the evolu=
tion of complexity by skipping this step.
> > 
> > I think it is a fascinat=
ing question and, unable to come up with 
a good
> > reason why development=
 matters myself, but wanting to give the
> argument a
> > rigorous evaluati=
on, I have been asking many people in our field 
whether
> > they can descr=
ibe something unique that a developmental process
> provides. No
> > one ha=
s come up with  a reason that compels me, so I have become a
> strong
> > a=
dvocate of the lack of a need for an unfolding process.
> > 
> > However, i=
n the course of watching a keynote on development in 
natural
> > systems a=
t this year's gecco, an argument in favor of development
> occurred
> > to =
me that may have merit. I am interested to hear what y'all 
think
> of it.
=
> > 
> > The argument is this: it might be easier to evolve certain large-
=
scale
> > properties when the organism is simple and small and then 
scale/=
grow
> them
> > up, rather than incorporating them into an already complex =

phenotype. I
> > think an example illustrates the point best. Imagine evol=
ution
> figuring out
> > how to put a coat of skin on an organism. It is no=
t that hard to
> figure out
> > what the shape of that skin should be when =
the embryo has only a 
few
> cells.
> > Once that simple and small coat of =
skin has formed, it can follow
> the simple
> > rule of keeping the layer o=
f skin the same thickness, and adding 
cells
> > within that layer to grow =
to cover any arbitrary shape that the
> phenotype
> > becomes. This simple =
rule could produce a skin shell for a bat or 
a
> jaguar.
> > Now consider =
how hard it would be for 3D hyperneat to create a 
skin
> shell
> > for a b=
at or a jaguar. The mathematical function to create such
> outlines is
> > =
very complex (although it is less so if it is a composition of 
other,
> > =
already created functions that produced the rest of the body). 
Still, it
>=
 > seems that this task might be harder for hyperneat than following
> the =
simple
> > developmental rules outlined above.
> > 
> > What do you think? =
I would happily be convinced that this 
argument is
> > without merit, so p=
lease let me know if you see any problems with 
it.
> > 
> > 
> > Cheers,
>=
 > Jeff Clune
> > 
> > Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> >=
 
> > jclune@
> >
